section.title: Verb patterns
section.sectiontitle: When one verb follows another, the second verb is either the -ing form or an infinitive.
section.sectiontitle2: Verbs of 'personal taste' are often followed by the -ing form: e.g. adore, fancy, don't mind, dislike, detest, can't stand.

section.title: Verb patterns
section.sectiontitle: Some verbs take an object + infinitive. Verbs that show one person (or thing) influencing the actions of another often follow this pattern, e.g. warn, tell, advise, urge, order, persuade, encourage, force, forbid, allow.
section.text2a: They persuaded us to meet them at the airport.
section.sectiontitle2: Verbs which are followed by a preposition use the -ing form, e.g. look forward to, subjected to, succeed in, benefit from.
section.text3a: I look forward to seeing you soon.
section.text4a: She kept on running even though she was tired.
